required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation for Post-Cesarean Pain Control
clinical_study.official_title: Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation for Post-Cesarean Pain Control

brief_summary.textblock: Purpose of study is to evaluate the efficacy of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for post-operative pain control after a cesarean delivery compared to placebo and no TENS.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants are randomized to one of three groups in parallel for the duration of the study
study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Total postoperative narcotic consumption (measured in morphine equivalents)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From date of cesarean delivery until discharge from hospital, assessed up to 1 month

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain assessed by numeric analog scale (NAS) (0-10; 0: no pain at all, 10: worst imaginable pain)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: On post-operative days 1, 2, 3, and day of discharge, assessed up to 1 month

secondary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction with pain control assessed by NAS (0-10; 0: very dissatisfied, 10: very satisfied)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: On post-operative days 1, 2, 3, and day of discharge, assessed up to 1 month
From date of randomization until date of discharge, assessed up to 1 month

intervention.description: Patients will be randomized to active TENS unit, placebo TENS unit, or no TENS unit

intervention.intervention_name: Placebo transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) unit
intervention.description: Patients will be randomized to active TENS unit, placebo TENS unit, or no TENS unit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women undergoing scheduled or non-urgent cesarean section
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English speaking
- Subjects with a history of chronic pain or chronic opioid use
- Pre-operative use of opioids for more than 1 week in the preceding 6 months
- Previous exposure to the TENS unit
- Women with an allergy or contraindication to narcotics/NSAIDs/acetaminophen
- Subjects who had a midline vertical skin incision during this operation
- Subjects who did not receive intrathecal opioids at the time of their cesarean delivery
- Adhesive allergies
- Subjects with a pacemaker (due to the unknown effects of the TENS on the electrical activity of the heart)
- Intraoperative general anesthesia
- Inability to consent to the study
- Postpartum tubal ligation
